books.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 1

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 1:1
verses.text: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation:.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 1:2
verses.text: The true Thesaurus; to wit, the Disputation conducted in Carchar, a city of Mesopotamia, before Manippus and aegialeus and Claudius and Cleobolus, who acted as judges.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 1:3
verses.text: In this city of Mesopotamia there was a certain man, Marcellus by name, who was esteemed as a person worthy of the highest honour for his manner of life, his pursuits, and his lineage, and not less so for his discretion and his nobility of character: he was possessed also of abundant means; and, what is most important of all, he feared God with the deepest piety, and gave ear always with due reverence to the things which were spoken of Christ.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 1:4
verses.text: In short, there was no good quality lacking in that man, and hence it came to pass that he was held in the greatest regard by the whole city; while, on the other hand, he also made an ample return for the good-will of his city by his munificent and oft-repeated acts of liberality in bestowing on the poor, relieving the afflicted, and giving help to the distressed.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 1:5
verses.text: But let it suffice us to have said thus much, lest by the weakness of our words we rather take from the man's virtues than adduce what is worthy of their splendour.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 1:6
verses.text: I shall come, therefore, to the task which forms my subject.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 1:7
verses.text: On a certain occasion, when a large body of captives were offered to the bishop Archelaus by the soldiers who held the camp in that place, their numbers being some seven thousand seven hundred, he was harassed with the keenest anxiety on account of the large sum of money which was demanded by the soldiers as the price of the prisoners' deliverance.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 1:8
verses.text: And as he could not conceal his solicitude, all aflame for the religion and the fear of God, he at length hastened to Marcellus, and explained to him the importance and difficulty of the case.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 1:9
verses.text: And when that pattern of piety, Marcellus, heard his narration, without the least delay he went into his house, and provided the price demanded for the prisoners, according to the value set upon them by those who had led them captive; and unlocking the treasures of his goods, he at once distributed the gifts of piety among the soldiers, without any severe consideration of number or distinction, so that they seemed to be presents rather than purchase-moneys.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 1:10
verses.text: And those soldiers were filled with wonder and admiration at the grandeur of the man's piety and munificence, and were struck with amazement, and felt the force of this example of pity; so that very many of them were added to the faith of our Lord Jesus Christ, and threw off the belt of military service, while others withdrew to their camp, taking scarcely a fourth part of the ransom, and the rest made their departure without receiving even so much as would defray the expenses of the way.

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:1
verses.text: Marcellus, as might well be expected, was exceedingly gratified by these incidents; and summoning one of the prisoners, by name Cortynius, he inquired of him the cause of the war, and by what chance it was that they were overcome and bound with the chains of captivity.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:2
verses.text: And the person addressed, on obtaining liberty to speak, began to express himself in these terms: "My lord Marcellus, we believe in the living God alone.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:3
verses.text: And we have a custom of such a nature as I shall now describe, which has descended to us by the tradition of our brethren in the faith, and has been regularly observed by us up to the present day.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:4
verses.text: The practice is, that every year we go out beyond the bounds of the city, in company with our wives and children, and offer up supplications to the only and invisible God, praying Him to send us rains for our fields and crops.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:5
verses.text: Now, when we were celebrating this observance at the usual time and in the wonted manner, evening surprised us as we lingered there, and were still fasting.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:6
verses.text: Thus we were feeling the pressure of two of the most trying things men have to endure,â€”namely, fasting and want of sleep.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:7
verses.text: But about midnight sleep enviously and inopportunely crept upon us, and with necks drooping and unstrung, and heads hanging down, it made our faces strike against our knees.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:8
verses.text: Now this took place because the time was at hand when by the judgment of God we were to pay the penalty proper to our deserts, whether it might be that we were offenders in ignorance, or whether it might be that with the consciousness of wrong we nevertheless had not given up our sin.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:9
verses.text: Accordingly at that hour a multitude of soldiers suddenly surrounded us, supposing us, as I judge, to have lodged ourselves in ambush there, and to be persons with full experience and skill in fighting battles; and without making any exact inquiry into the cause of our gathering there, they threatened us with war, not in word, but at once by the sword.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:10
verses.text: And though we were men who had never learned to do injury to any one, they wounded us pitilessly with their missiles, and thrust us through with their spears, and cut our throats with their swords.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:11
verses.text: Thus they slew, indeed, about one thousand and three hundred men of our number, and wounded other five hundred.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:12
verses.text: And when the day broke clearly, they carried off the survivors amongst us as prisoners here, and that, too, in a way showing their utter want of pity for us.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:13
verses.text: For they drove us before their horses, spurring us on by blows from their spears, and impelling us forward by making the horses' heads press upon us.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:14
verses.text: And those who had sufficient powers of endurance did indeed hold out; but very many fell down before the face of their cruel masters, and breathed out their life there; and mothers, with arms wearied, and utterly powerless with their burdens, and distracted by the threats of those behind them, suffered the little ones that were hanging on their breasts to fall to the ground; while all those on whom old age had come were sinking, one after the other, to the earth, overcome with their toils, and exhausted by want of food.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:15
verses.text: The proud soldiers nevertheless enjoyed this bloody spectacle of men continually perishing, as if it had been a kind of entertainment, while they saw some stretched on the soil in hopeless prostration, and beheld others, worn out by the fierce fires of thirst and with the bands of their tongues utterly parched, lose the power of speech, and beheld others with eyes ever glancing backwards, groaning over the fate of their dying little ones, while these, again, were constantly appealing to their most unhappy mothers with their cries, and the mothers themselves, driven frantic by the severities of the robbers, responded with their lamentations, which indeed was the only thing they could do freely.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:16
verses.text: And those of them whose hearts were most tenderly bound up with their offspring chose voluntarily to meet the same premature fate of death with their children; while those, on the other hand, who had some capacity of endurance were carried off prisoners here with us.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 2:17
verses.text: Thus, after the lapse of three days, during which time we had never been allowed to take any rest, even in the night, we were conveyed to this place, in which what has now taken place after these occurrences is better known to yourself".

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 3

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 3:1
verses.text: When Marcellus, the man of consummate piety, had heard this recital, he burst into a flood of tears, touched with pity for misfortunes so great and so various.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 3:2
verses.text: But making no delay, he at once prepared victuals for the sufferers, and did service with his own hand for the wearied; in this imitating our father Abraham the patriarch, who, when he entertained the angels hospitably on a certain occasion, did not content himself with merely giving the order to his slaves to bring a calf from the herd, but did himself, though advanced in years, go and place it on his shoulders and fetch it in, and did with his own hand prepare food, and set it before the angels.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 3:3
verses.text: So Marcellus, in discharge of a similar office, directed them to be seated as his guests in companies of ten; and when the seven hundred tables were all provided, he refreshed the whole body of the captives with great delight, so that those who had strength to survive what they had been called to endure, forgot their toils, and became oblivious of all their ills.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 3:4
verses.text: When, however, they had reached the fifteenth day, and while Marcellus was still liberally supplying all things needful for the prisoners, it seemed good to him that they should all be put in possession of the means of returning to their own parts, with the exception of those who were detained by the attention which their wounds demanded; and providing the proper remedies for these, he instructed the rest to depart to their own country and friends.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 3:5
verses.text: And even to all these charities Marcellus added yet larger deeds of piety.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 3:6
verses.text: For with a numerous band of his own dependants he went to look after the burying of the bodies of those who had perished on the march; and for as many of these as he could discover, of whatsoever condition, he secured the sepulture which was meet for them.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 3:7
verses.text: And when this service was completed he returned to Charra, and gave permission to the wounded to return thence to their native country when their health was sufficiently restored, providing also most liberal supplies for their use on their journey.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 3:8
verses.text: And truly the estimate of this deed made a magnificent addition to the repute of the other noble actions of Marcellus; for through that whole territory the fame of the piety of Marcellus spread so grandly, that large numbers of men belonging to various cities were inflamed with the intensest desire to see and become acquainted with the man, and most especially those persons who had not had occasion to bear penury before,â€”to all of whom this remarkable man, following the example of a Marcellus of old, furnished aid most indulgently, so that they all declared that there was no one of more illustrious piety than this man.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 3:9
verses.text: Yea, all the widows, too, who were believers in the Lord had recourse to him, while the imbecile also could reckon on obtaining at his hand most certain help to meet their circumstances; and the orphaned, in like manner, were all supported by him, so that his house was declared to be the hospice for the stranger and the indigent.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 3:10
verses.text: And above all this, he retained in a remarkable and singular measure his devotion to the faith, building up his own heart upon the rock that shall not be moved.

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 4

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 4:1
verses.text: Accordingly, as this man's fame was becoming always the more extensively diffused throughout different localities, and when it had now penetrated even beyond the river Stranga, the honourable report of his name was carried into the territory of Persia.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 4:2
verses.text: In this country dwelt a person called Manes, who, when this man's repute had reached him, deliberated largely with himself as to how he might entangle him in the snares of his doctrine, hoping that Marcellus might be made an upholder of his dogma.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 4:3
verses.text: For he reckoned that he might make himself master of the whole province, if he could only first attach such a man to himself.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 4:4
verses.text: In this project, however, his mind was agitated with the doubt whether he should at once repair in person to the man, or first attempt to get at him by letter; for he was afraid lest, by any sudden and unexpected introduction of himself upon the scene some mischance might possibly befall him.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 4:5
verses.text: At last, in obedience to a subtler policy, he resolved to write; and calling to him one of his disciples, by name Turbo, who had been instructed by Addas, he handed to him an epistle, and bade him depart and convey it to Marcellus.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 4:6
verses.text: This adherent accordingly received the letter, and carried it to the person to whom he had been commissioned by Manes to deliver it, overtaking the whole journey within five days.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 4:7
verses.text: The above-mentioned Turbo, indeed, used great expedition on this journey, in the course of which he also underwent very considerable exertion and trouble.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 4:8
verses.text: For whenever he arrived, as a traveller in foreign parts, at a hospice,â€”and these were inns which Marcellus himself had supplied in his large hospitality,â€”on his being asked by the keepers of these hostels whence he came, and who he was, or by whom he had been sent, he used to reply: "I belong to the district of Mesopotamia, but I come at present from Persis, having been sent by Manichaeus, a master among the Christians".

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 4:9
verses.text: But they were by no means ready to welcome a name unknown to them, and were wont sometimes to thrust Turbo out of their inns, refusing him even the means of getting water for drinking purposes.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 4:10
verses.text: And as he had to bear daily things like these, and things even worse than these, at the hands of those persons in the several localities who had charge of the mansions and hospices, unless he had at last shown that he was conveying letters to Marcellus, Turbo would have met the doom of death in his travels.

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 5

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 5:1
verses.text: On receiving the epistle, then, Marcellus opened it, and read it in the presence of Archelaus, the bishop of the place.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 5:2
verses.text: And the following is a copy of what it contained:â€”  Manichaeus, an apostle of Jesus Christ, and all the saints who are with me, and the virgins, to Marcellus, my beloved son: Grace, mercy, and peace be with you from God the Father, and from our Lord Jesus Christ; and may the right hand of light preserve you safe from this present evil world, and from its calamities, and from the snares of the wicked one, Amen.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 5:3
verses.text: I was exceedingly delighted to observe the love cherished by you, which truly is of the largest measure.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 5:4
verses.text: But I was distressed at your faith, which is not in accordance with the right standard.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 5:5
verses.text: Wherefore, deputed as I am to seek the elevation of the race of men, and sparing, as I do, those who have given themselves over to deceit and error, I have considered it needful to despatch this letter to you, with a view, in the first place, to the salvation of your own soul, and in the second place also to that of the souls of those who are with you, so as to secure you against dubious opinions, and specially against notions like those in which the guides of the simpler class of minds indoctrinate their subjects, when they allege that good and evil have the same original subsistence, and when they posit the same beginning for them, without making any distinction or discrimination between light and darkness, and between the good and the evil or worthless, and between the inner man and the outer, as we have stated before, and without ceasing to mix up and confound together the one with the other.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 5:6
verses.text: But, O my son, refuse thou thus thoughtlessly to identify these two things in the irrational and foolish fashion common to the mass of men, and ascribe no such confusion to the God of goodness.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 5:7
verses.text: For these men refer the beginning and the end and the paternity of these ills to God Himself,â€”"whose end is near a curse".

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 5:8
verses.text: For they do not believe the word spoken by our Saviour and Lord Jesus Christ Himself in the Gospels, namely, that "a good tree cannot bring forth evil fruit, neither can a corrupt tree bring forth good fruit".

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 5:9
verses.text: And how they can be bold enough to call God the maker and contriver of Satan and his wicked deeds, is a matter of great amazement to me.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 5:10
verses.text: Yea, would that even this had been all the length to which they had gone with their silly efforts, and that they had not declared that the only-begotten Christ, who has descended from the bosom of the Father, is the son of a certain woman, Mary, and born of blood and flesh and the varied impurities proper to women! Howbeit, neither to write too much in this epistle, nor to trespass at too great length upon your good nature,â€”and all the more so that I have no natural gift of eloquence,â€”I shall content myself with what I have said.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 5:11
verses.text: But you will have full knowledge of the whole subject when I am present with you, if indeed you still continue to care for your own salvation.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 5:12
verses.text: For I do not "cast a snare upon any one," as is done by the less thoughtful among the mass of men.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 5:13
verses.text: Think of what I say, most honourable son.

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:1
verses.text: On reading this epistle, Marcellus, with the kindest consideration, attended hospitably to the needs of the bearer of the letter.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:2
verses.text: Archelaus, on the other hand, did not receive very pleasantly the matters which were read, but "gnashed with his teeth like a chained lion," impatient to have the author of the epistle given over to him.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:3
verses.text: Marcellus, however, counselled him to be at peace; promising that he would himself take care to secure the man's presence.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:4
verses.text: And accordingly Marcellus resolved to send an answer to what had been written to him, and indited an epistle containing the following statements:â€”  Marcellus, a man of distinction, to Manichaeus, who has made himself known to me by his epistle, greeting.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:5
verses.text: An epistle written by you has come to my hand, and I have received Turbo with my wonted kindness; but the meaning of your letter I have by no means apprehended, and may not do so unless you give us your presence, and explain its contents in detail in the way of conversation, as you have offered to do in the epistle itself.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:6
verses.text: Farewell.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:7
verses.text: This letter he sealed and handed to Turbo, with instructions to deliver it to the person from whom he had already conveyed a similar document.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:8
verses.text: The messenger, however, was extremely reluctant to return to his master, being mindful of what he had to endure on the journey, and begged that another person should be despatched in his stead, refusing to go back to Manes, or to have any intercourse whatever with him again.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:9
verses.text: But Marcellus summoned one of his young men, Callistus by name, and directed him to proceed to the place.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:10
verses.text: Without any loss of time this young man set out promptly on his journey thither; and after the lapse of three days he came to Manes, whom he found in a certain fort, that of Arabion to wit, and to whom he presented the epistle.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:11
verses.text: On perusing it, he was glad to see that he had been invited by Marcellus; and without delay he undertook the journey; yet he had a presentiment that Turbo's failure to return boded no good, and proceeded on his way to Marcellus, not, as it were, without serious reflections.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:12
verses.text: Turbo, for his part, was not at all thinking of leaving the house of Marcellus; neither did he omit any opportunity of conversing with Archelaus the bishop.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:13
verses.text: For both these parties were very diligently engaged in investigating the practices of Manichaeus, being desirous of knowing who he was and whence he came, and what was his manner of discourse.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:14
verses.text: And he, Turbo, accordingly gave a lucid account of the whole position, narrating and expounding the terms of his faith in the following manner:â€”  If you are desirous of being instructed in the faith of Manes by me, attend to me for a short space.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:15
verses.text: That man worships two deities, unoriginated, self-existent, eternal, opposed the one to the other.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:16
verses.text: Of these he represents the one as good, and the other as evil, and assigns the name of Light to the former, and that of Darkness to the latter.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:17
verses.text: He alleges also that the soul in men is a portion of the light, but that the body and the formation of matter are parts of the darkness.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:18
verses.text: He maintains, further, that a certain commingling or blending has been effected between the two in the manner about to be stated, the following analogy being used as an illustration of the same; to wit, that their relations may be likened to those of two kings in conflict with each other, who are antagonists from the beginning, and have their own positions, each in his due order.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:19
verses.text: And so he holds that the darkness passed without its own boundaries, and engaged in a similar contention with the light; but that the good Father then, perceiving that the darkness had come to sojourn on His earth, put forth from Himself a power which is called the Mother of Life; and that this power thereupon put forth from itself the first man, and the five elements.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:20
verses.text: And these five elements are wind, light, water, fire, and matter.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:21
verses.text: Now this primitive man, being endued with these, and thereby equipped, as it were, for war, descended to these lower parts, and made war against the darkness.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:22
verses.text: But the princes of the darkness, waging war in turn against him, consumed that portion of his panoply which is the soul.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:23
verses.text: Then was that first man grievously injured there underneath by the darkness; and had it not been that the Father heard his prayers, and sent a second power, which was also put forth from Himself and was called the living Spirit, and came down and gave him the right hand, and brought him up again out of the grasp of the darkness, that first man would, in those ancient times, have been in peril of absolute overthrow.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:24
verses.text: From that time, consequently, he left the soul beneath.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:25
verses.text: And for this reason the Manichaeans, if they meet each other, give the right hand, in token of their having been saved from darkness; for he holds that the heresies have their seat all in the darkness.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:26
verses.text: Then the living Spirit created the world; and bearing in himself three other powers, he came down and brought off the princes, and settled them in the firmament, which is their body, (though it is called) the sphere.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:27
verses.text: Then, again, the living Spirit created the luminaries, which are fragments of the soul, and he made them thus to move round and round the firmament; and again he created the earth in its eight species.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:28
verses.text: And the Omophorus sustains the burden thereof beneath; and when he is wearied with bearing it he trembles, and in that manner becomes the cause of a quaking of the earth in contravention of its determinate times.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:29
verses.text: On account of this the good Father sent His Son forth from His own bosom into the heart of the earth, and into these lowest parts of it, in order to secure for him the correction befitting him.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:30
verses.text: And whenever an earthquake occurs, he is either trembling under his weariness, or is shifting his burden from one shoulder to the other.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:31
verses.text: Thereafter, again, the matter also of itself produced growths; and when these were carried off as spoil on the part of some of the princes, he summoned together all the foremost of the princes, and took from all of them individually power after power, and made up the man who is after the image of that first man, and united the soul (with these powers) in him.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 6:32
verses.text: This is the account of the manner in which his constitution was planned.

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:1
verses.text: But when the living Father perceived that the soul was in tribulation in the body, being full of mercy and compassion, He sent His own beloved Son for the salvation of the soul.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:2
verses.text: For this, together with the matter of Omophorus, was the reason of His sending Him.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:3
verses.text: And the Son came and transformed Himself into the likeness of man, and manifested Himself to men as a man, while yet He was not a man, and men supposed that He was begotten.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:4
verses.text: Thus He came and prepared the work which was to effect the salvation of the souls, and with that object constructed an instrument with twelve urns, which is made to revolve by the sphere, and draws up with it the souls of the dying.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:5
verses.text: And the greater luminary receives these souls, and purifies them with its rays, and then passes them over to the moon; and in this manner the moon's disc, as it is designated by us, is filled up.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:6
verses.text: For he says that these two luminaries are ships or passage-boats.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:7
verses.text: Then, if the moon becomes full, it ferries its passengers across toward the east wind, and thereby effects its own waning in getting itself delivered of its freight.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:8
verses.text: And in this manner it goes on making the passage across, and again discharging its freight of souls drawn up by the urns, until it saves its own proper portion of the souls.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:9
verses.text: Moreover, he maintains that every soul, yea, every living creature that moves, partakes of the substance of the good Father.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:10
verses.text: And accordingly, when the moon delivers over its freight of souls to the aeons of the Father, they abide there in that pillar of glory, which is called the perfect air.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:11
verses.text: And this air is a pillar of light, for it is filled with the souls that are being purified.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:12
verses.text: Such, moreover, is the agency by which the souls are saved.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:13
verses.text: But the following, again, is the cause of men's dying: A certain virgin, fair in person, and beautiful in attire, and of most persuasive address, aims at making spoil of the princes that have been borne up and crucified on the firmament by the living Spirit; and she appears as a comely female to the princes, but as a handsome and attractive young man to the princesses.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:14
verses.text: And the princes, when they look on her in her splendid figure, are smitten with love's sting; and as they are unable to get possession of her, they burn fiercely with the flame of amorous desire, and lose all power of reason.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:15
verses.text: While they thus pursue the virgin, she disappears from view.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:16
verses.text: Then the great prince sends forth from himself the clouds, with the purpose of bringing darkness on the whole world, in his anger.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:17
verses.text: And then, if he feels grievously oppressed, his exhaustion expresses itself in perspiration, just as a man sweats under toil; and this sweat of his forms the rain.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:18
verses.text: At the same time also the harvest-prince, if he too chances to be captivated by the virgin, scatters pestilence on the whole earth, with the view of putting men to death.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:19
verses.text: Now this body (of man) is also called a cosmos, i-e:, a microcosm, in relation to the great cosmos, i-e:, the macrocosm of the universe; and all men have roots which are linked beneath with those above.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:20
verses.text: Accordingly, when this prince is captivated by the virgin's charms, he then begins to cut the roots of men; and when their roots are cut, then pestilence commences to break forth, and in that manner they die.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:21
verses.text: And if he shakes the upper parts of the root mightily, an earthquake bursts, and follows as the consequence of the commotion to which the Omophorus is subjected.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 7:22
verses.text: This is the explanation of (the phenomenon of) death.

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:1
verses.text: I shall explain to you also how it is that the soul is transfused into five bodies.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:2
verses.text: First of all, in this process some small portion of it is purified; and then it is transfused into the body of a dog, or a camel, or some other animal.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:3
verses.text: But if the soul has been guilty of homicide, it is translated into the body of the celephi; and if it has been found to have engaged in cutting; it is made to pass into the body of the dumb.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:4
verses.text: Now these are the designations of the soul,â€”namely, intelligence, reflection, prudence, consideration, reasoning.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:5
verses.text: Moreover, the reapers who reap are likened to the princes who have been in darkness from the beginning, since they consumed somewhat of the panoply of the first man.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:6
verses.text: On this account there is a necessity for these to be translated into hay, or beans, or barley, or corn, or vegetables, in order that in these forms they, in like manner, may be reaped and cut.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:7
verses.text: And again, if any one eats bread, he must needs also become bread and be eaten.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:8
verses.text: If one kills a chicken, he will be a chicken himself.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:9
verses.text: If one kills a mouse, he will also become a mouse himself.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:10
verses.text: If, again, one is wealthy in this world, it is necessary that, on quitting the tabernacle of his body, he should be made to pass into the body of a beggar, so as to go about asking alms, and thereafter he shall depart into everlasting punishment.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:11
verses.text: Moreover, as this body pertains to the princes and to matter, it is necessary that he who plants a persea should pass though many bodies until that persea is prostrated.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:12
verses.text: And if one builds a house for himself, he will be divided and scattered among all the bodies.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:13
verses.text: If one bathes in water, he freezes his soul; and if one refuses to give pious regard to his elect, he will be punished through the generations, and will be translated into the bodies of catechumens, until he render many tributes of piety; and for this reason they offer to the elect whatever is best in their meats.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:14
verses.text: And when they are about to eat bread, they offer up prayer first of all, addressing themselves in these terms to the bread: "I have neither reaped thee, nor ground thee, nor pressed thee, nor cast thee into the baking-vessel; but another has done these things, and brought thee to me, and I have eaten thee without fault".

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:15
verses.text: And when he has uttered these things to himself, he says to the catechumen, "I have prayed for thee;" and in this manner that person then takes his departure.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:16
verses.text: For, as I remarked to you a little before, if any one reaps, he will be reaped; and so, too, if one casts grain into the mill, he will be cast in himself in like manner, or if he kneads he will be kneaded, or if he bakes he will be baked; and for this reason they are interdicted from doing any such work.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:17
verses.text: Moreover, there are certain other worlds on which the luminaries rise when they have set on our world.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:18
verses.text: And if a person walks upon the ground here, he injures the earth; and if he moves his hand, he injures the air; for the air is the soul (life) of men and living creatures, both fowl, and fish, and creeping thing.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 8:19
verses.text: And as to every one existing in this world, I have told you that this body of his does not pertain to God, but to matter, and is itself darkness, and consequently it must needs be cast in darkness.

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:1
verses.text: Now, with respect to paradise, it is not called a cosmos.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:2
verses.text: The trees that are in it are lust and other seductions, which corrupt the rational powers of those men.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:3
verses.text: And that tree in paradise, by which men know the good, is Jesus Himself, or the knowledge of Him in the world.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:4
verses.text: He who partakes thereof discerns the good and the evil.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:5
verses.text: The world itself, however, is not God's work; but it was the structure of a portion of matter, and consequently all things perish in it.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:6
verses.text: And what the princes took as spoil from the first man, that is what makes the moon full, and what is being purged day by day of the world.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:7
verses.text: And if the soul makes its exit without having gained the knowledge of the truth, it is given over to the demons, in order that they may subdue it in the Gehennas of fire; and after that discipline it is made to pass into bodies with the purpose of being brought into subjection, and in this manner it is cast into the mighty fire until the consummation.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:8
verses.text: Again, regarding the prophets amongst you, he speaks thus: Their spirit is one of impiety, or of the lawlessness of the darkness which arose at the beginning.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:9
verses.text: And being deceived by this spirit, they have not spoken truth; for the prince blinded their mind.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:10
verses.text: And if any one follows their words, he dies for ever, bound to the clods of earth, because he has not learned the knowledge of the Paraclete.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:11
verses.text: He also gave injunctions to his elect alone, who are not more than seven in number.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:12
verses.text: And the charge was this: "When ye cease eating, pray, and put upon your head an olive, sworn with the invocation of many names for the confirmation of this faith".

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:13
verses.text: The names, however, were not made known to me; for only these seven make use of them.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:14
verses.text: And again, the name Sabaoth, which is honourable and mighty with you, he declares to be the nature of man, and the parent of desire; for which reason the simple worship desire, and hold it to be a deity.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:15
verses.text: Furthermore, as regards the manner of the creation of Adam, he tells us that he who said, "Come and let us make man in our image, after our likeness," or "after the form which we have seen," is the prince who addressed the other princes in terms which may be thus interpreted: "Come, give me of the light which we have received, and let us make man after the form of us princes, even after that form which we have seen, that is to say, the first man".

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:16
verses.text: And in that manner he created the man.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:17
verses.text: They created Eve also after the like fashion, imparting to her of their own lust, with a view to the deceiving of Adam.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 9:18
verses.text: And by these means the construction of the world proceeded from the operations of the prince.

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 10

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 10:1
verses.text: He holds also that God has no part with the world itself, and finds no pleasure in it, by reason of its having been made a spoil of from the first by the princes, and on account of the ill that rose on it.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 10:2
verses.text: Wherefore He sends and takes away from them day by day the soul belonging to Him, through the medium of these luminaries, the sun and the moon, by which the whole world and all creation are dominated.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 10:3
verses.text: Him, again, who spake with Moses, and the Jews, and the priests, he declares to be the prince of the darkness; so that the Christians, and the Jews, and the Gentiles are one and the same body, worshipping the same God: for He seduces them in His own passions, being no God of truth.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 10:4
verses.text: For this reason all those who hope in that God who spake with Moses and the prophets have to be bound together with the said deity, because they have not hoped in the God of truth; for that deity spake with him in accordance with their own passions.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 10:5
verses.text: Moreover, after all these things, he speaks in the following terms with regard to the end, as he has also written: When the elder has displayed his image, the Omophorus then lets the earth go from him, and so the mighty fire gets free, and consumes the whole world.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 10:6
verses.text: Then, again, he lets the soil go with the new aeon, in order that all the souls of sinners may be bound for ever.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 10:7
verses.text: These things will take place at the time when the man's image has come.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 10:8
verses.text: And all these powers put forth by God,â€”namely, Jesus, who is in the smaller ship, and the Mother of Life, and the twelve helmsmen, and the virgin of the light, and the third elder, who is in the greater ship, and the living spirit, and the wall of the mighty fire, and the wall of the wind, and the air, and the water, and the interior living fire,â€”have their seat in the lesser luminary, until the fire shall have consumed the whole world: and that is to happen within so many years, the exact number of which, however, I have not ascertained.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 10:9
verses.text: And after these things there will be a restitution of the two natures; and the princes will occupy the lower parts proper to them, and the Father the higher parts, receiving again what is His own due possession.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 10:10
verses.text: â€”All this doctrine he delivered to his three disciples, and charged each to journey to a separate clime.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 10:11
verses.text: The Eastern parts fell thus to the lot of Addas; Thomas obtained the Syrian territories as his heritage; and another, to wit, Hermeias, directed his course towards Egypt.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 10:12
verses.text: And to this day they, sojourn there, with the purpose of establishing the propositions contained in this doctrine.

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 11

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 11:1
verses.text: When Turbo had made this statement, Archelaus was intensely excited; but Marcellus remained unmoved, for he expected that God would come to the help of His truth.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 11:2
verses.text: Archelaus, however, had additional cares in his anxiety about the people, like the shepherd who becomes concerned for his sheep when secret perils threaten them from the wolves.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 11:3
verses.text: Accordingly Marcellus loaded Turbo with the most liberal gifts, and instructed him to remain in the house of Archelaus the bishop.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 11:4
verses.text: But on that selfsame day Manes arrived, bringing along with him certain chosen youths and virgins to the number of twenty-two.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 11:5
verses.text: And first of all he sought for Turbo at the door of the house of Marcellus; and on failing to find him there, he went in to salute Marcellus.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 11:6
verses.text: On seeing him, Marcellus at first was struck with astonishment at the costume in which he presented himself.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 11:7
verses.text: For he wore a kind of shoe which is usually called in common speech the quadrisole; he had also a party-coloured cloak, of a somewhat airy appearance; in his hand he grasped a very sturdy staff of ebony-wood; he carried a Babylonian book under his left arm; his legs were swathed in trousers of different colours, the one being red, and the other green as a leek; and his whole mien was like that of some old Persian master and commandant.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 11:8
verses.text: Thereupon Marcellus sent forthwith for Archelaus, who arrived so quickly as almost to outstrip the word, and on entering was greatly tempted at once to break out against him, being provoked to that instantly by the very sight of his costume and his appearance, though more especially also by the fact that he had himself been turning over in his mind in his retirement the various matters which he had learned from the recital of Turbo, and had thus come carefully prepared.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 11:9
verses.text: But Marcellus, in his great thoughtfulness, repressed all zeal for mere wrangling, and decided to hear both parties.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 11:10
verses.text: With that view he invited the leading men of the city; and from among them he selected as judges of the discussion certain adherents of the Gentile religion, four in number.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 11:11
verses.text: The names of these umpires were as follows: Manippus, a person deeply versed in the art of grammar and the practice of rhetoric; aegialeus, a very eminent physician, and a man of the highest reputation for learning; and Claudius and Cleobolus, two brothers famed as rhetoricians.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 11:12
verses.text: A splendid assemblage was thus convened; so large, indeed, that the house of Marcellus, which was of immense size, was filled with those who had been called to be hearers.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 11:13
verses.text: And when the parties who proposed to speak in opposition to each other had taken their places in view of all, then those who had been elected as judges took their seats in a position elevated above all others: and the task of commencing the disputation was assigned to Manes.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 11:14
verses.text: Accordingly, when silence was secured, he began the discussion in the following terms:â€”.

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:1
verses.text: My brethren, I indeed am a disciple of Christ, and, moreover, an apostle of Jesus; and it is owing to the exceeding kindness of Marcellus that I have hastened hither, with the view of showing him clearly in what manner he ought to keep the system of divine religion, so that the said Marcellus verily, who at present has put himself, like one who has surrendered himself prisoner, under the doctrine of Archelaus, may not, like the dumb animals, which are destitute of intellect and understand not what they do, be fatally smitten to the ruin of his soul, in consequence of any failure in the possession of further facilities for setting about the right observance of divine worship.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:2
verses.text: I know, furthermore, and am certain, that if Marcellus is once set right, it will be quite possible that all of you may also have your salvation effected; for your city hangs suspended upon his judgment.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:3
verses.text: If vain presumption is rejected by every one of you, and if those things which are to be declared by me be heard with a real love for the truth, ye will receive the inheritance of the age to come, and the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:4
verses.text: I, in sooth, am the Paraclete, whose mission was announced of old time by Jesus, and who was to come to "convince the world of sin and unrighteousness".

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:5
verses.text: And even as Paul, who was sent before me, said of himself, that "he knew in part, and prophesied in part," so I reserve the perfect for myself, in order that I may do away with that which is in part.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:6
verses.text: Therefore receive ye this third testimony, that I am an elect apostle of Christ; and if ye choose to accept my words, ye will find salvation; but if ye refuse them, eternal fire will have you to consume you.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:7
verses.text: For as Hymenaeus and Alexander were "delivered unto Satan, that they might learn not to blaspheme," so will all ye also be delivered unto the prince of punishments, because ye have done injury to the Father of Christ, in so far as ye declare Him to be the cause of all evils, and the founder of unrighteousness, and the creator of all iniquity.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:8
verses.text: By such doctrine ye do, indeed, bring forth from the same fountain both sweet water and bitter,â€”a thing which can in no possible way be either done or apprehended.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:9
verses.text: For who ought to be believed? Should it be those masters of yours whose enjoyment is in the flesh, and who pamper themselves with the richest delights; or our Saviour Jesus Christ, who says, as it is written in the book of the Gospels, "A good tree cannot bring forth evil fruit, neither can a corrupt tree bring forth good fruit," and who in another place assures us that the "father of the devil is a liar and a murderer from the beginning," and tells us again that men's desire was for the darkness, so that they would not follow that Word that had been sent forth in the beginning from the light, and (once more shows us) the man who is the enemy of the same, the sower of tares, and the god and prince of the age of this world, who blinds the minds of men that they may not be obedient to the truth in the Gospel of Christ? Is that God good who has no wish that the men who are his own should be saved? And, not to go over a multitude of other matters, and waste much time, I may defer till another opportunity the exposition of the true doctrine; and taking it for granted that I have said enough on this subject for the present, I may revert to the matter immediately before me, and endeavour satisfactorily to demonstrate the absurdity of these men's teaching, and show that none of these things can be attributed to the God and Father of our Lord and Saviour, but that we must take Satan to be the cause of all our ills.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:10
verses.text: To him, certainly, these must be carried back, for all ills of this kind are generated by him.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:11
verses.text: But those things also which are written in the prophets and the law are none the less to be ascribed to him; for he it is who spake then in the prophets, introducing into their minds very many ignorant notions of God, as well as temptations and passions.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:12
verses.text: They, too, set forth that devourer of blood and flesh; and to that Satan and to his prophets all these things properly pertain which he wished to transfer to the Father of Christ, prepared as he was to write a few things in the way of truth, that by means of these he might also gain credence for those other statements of his which are false.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:13
verses.text: Hence it is well for us to receive nothing at all of all those things which have been written of old even down to John, and indeed to embrace only the kingdom of heaven, which has been preached in the Gospel since his days; for they verily but made a mockery of themselves, introducing as they did things ridiculous and ludicrous, keeping some small words given in obscure outline in the law, but not understanding that, if good things are mixed up with evil, the result is, that by the corruption of these evil things, even those others which are good are destroyed.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:14
verses.text: And if, indeed, there is any one who may prove himself able to demonstrate that the law upholds the right, that law ought to be kept; but if we can show it to be evil, then it ought to be done away with and rejected, inasmuch as it contains the ministration of death, which was graven, which also covered and destroyed the glory on the countenance of Moses.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:15
verses.text: It is a thing not without peril, therefore, for any one of you to teach the New Testament along with the law and the prophets, as if they were of one and the same origin; for the knowledge of our Saviour renews the one from day to day, while the other grows old and infirm, and passes almost into utter destruction.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:16
verses.text: And this is a fact manifest to those who are capable of exercising discernment.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:17
verses.text: For just as, when the branches of a tree become aged, or when the trunk ceases to bear fruit any more, they are cut down; and just as, when the members of the body suffer mortification, they are amputated, for the poison of the mortification diffuses itself from these members through the whole body, and unless some remedy be found for the disease by the skill of the physician, the whole body will be vitiated; so, too, if ye receive the law without understanding its origin, ye will ruin your souls, and lose your salvation.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:18
verses.text: For "the law and the prophets were until John;" but since John the law of truth, the law of the promises, the law of heaven, the new law, is made known to the race of man.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:19
verses.text: And, in sooth, as long as there was no one to exhibit to you this most true knowledge of our Lord Jesus, ye had not sin.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:20
verses.text: Now, however, ye both see and hear, and yet ye desire to walk in ignorance, in order that ye may keep that law which has been destroyed and abandoned.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:21
verses.text: And Paul, too, who is held to be the most approved apostle with us, expresses himself to the same effect in one of his epistles, when he says: "For if I build again the things which I destroyed, I make myself a prevaricator".

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 12:22
verses.text: And in saying this he pronounces on them as Gentiles, because they were under the elements of the world, before the fulness of faith came, believing then as they did in the law and the prophets.

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 13

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 13:1
verses.text: The judges said: If you have any clearer statement yet to make, give us some explanation of the nature of your doctrine and the designation of your faith.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 13:2
verses.text: Manes replied: I hold that there are two natures, one good and another evil; and that the one which is good dwells indeed in certain parts proper to it, but that the evil one is this world, as well as all things in it, which are placed there like objects imprisoned in the portion of the wicked one, as John says, that "the whole world lieth in wickedness," and not in God.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 13:3
verses.text: Wherefore we have maintained that there are two localities,â€”one good, and another which lies outside of this, so that, having space therein in his, it might be capable of receiving into itself the creature, i-e:, creation, of the world.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 13:4
verses.text: For if we say that there is but a monarchy of one nature, and that God fills all things, and that there is no location outside of Him, what will be the sustainer of the creature, i-e:, creation? where will be the Gehenna of fire? where the outer darkness? where the weeping? Shall I say in Himself? God forbid; else He Himself will also be made to suffer in and with these.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 13:5
verses.text: Entertain no such fancies, whosoever of you have any care for your salvation; for I shall give you an example, in order that you may have fuller understanding of the truth.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 13:6
verses.text: The world is one vessel; and if the substance of God has already filled this entire vessel, how is it possible now that anything more can be placed in this same vessel? If it is full, how shall it receive what is placed in it, unless a certain portion of the vessel is emptied? Or whither shall that which is to be emptied out make its way, seeing that there is no locality for it? Where then is the earth? where the heavens? where the abyss? where the stars? where the settlements? where the powers? where the princes? where the outer darkness? Who is he that has laid the foundations of these, and where? No one is able to tell us that without stumbling on blasphemy.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 13:7
verses.text: And in what way, again, has He been able to make the creatures, if there is no subsistent matter? For if He has made them out of the non-existent, it will follow that these visible creatures should be superior, and full of all virtues.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 13:8
verses.text: But if in these there are wickedness, and death, and corruption, and whatever is opposed to the good, how say we that they owe their formation to a nature different from themselves? Howbeit if you consider the way in which the sons of men are begotten, you will find that the creator of man is not the Lord, but another being, who is also himself of an unbegotten nature, who has neither founder, nor creator, nor maker, but who, such as he is, has been produced by his own malice alone.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 13:9
verses.text: In accordance with this, you men have a commerce with your wives, which comes to you by an occasion of the following nature.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 13:10
verses.text: When any one of you has satiated himself with carnal meats, and meats of other kinds, then the impulse of concupiscence rises in him, and in this way the enjoyment of begetting a son is increased; and this happens not as if that had its spring in any virtue, or in philosophy, or in any other gift of mind, but in fulness of meats only, and in lust and fornication.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 13:11
verses.text: And how shall any one tell me that our father Adam was made after the image of God, and in His likeness, and that he is like Him who made him? How can it be said that all of us who have been begotten of him are like him? Yea, rather, on the contrary, have we not a great variety of forms, and do we not bear the impress of different countenances? And how true this is, I shall exhibit to you in parables.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 13:12
verses.text: Look, for instance, at a person who wishes to seal up a treasure, or some other object, and you will observe how, when he has got a little wax or clay, he seeks to stamp it with an impression of his own countenance from the ring which he wears; but if another countenance also stamps the figure of itself on the object in a similar manner, will the impression seem like? By no means, although you may be reluctant to acknowledge what is true.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 13:13
verses.text: But if we are not like in the common impression, and if, instead of that, there are differences in us, how can it fail to be proved thereby that we are the workmanship of the princes, and of matter? For in due accordance with their form, and likeness, and image, we also exist as diverse forms.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 13:14
verses.text: But if you wish to be fully instructed as to that commerce which took place at the beginning, and as to the manner in which it occurred, I shall explain the matter to you.

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:1
verses.text: The judges said: We need not inquire as to the manner in which that primitive commerce took place until we have first seen it proved that there are two natural principles.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:2
verses.text: For when once it is made clear that there are two unbegotten natures, then others of your averments may also gain our assent, even although something in them may not seem to fit in very readily with what is credible.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:3
verses.text: For as the power of pronouncing judgment has been committed to us, we shall declare what may make itself clear to our mind.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:4
verses.text: We may, however, also grant to Archelaus the liberty of speaking to these statements of yours, so that, by comparing what is said by each of you, we may be able to give our decision in accordance with the truth.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:5
verses.text: Archelaus said: Notwithstanding, the adversary's intent is replete with gross audacity and blasphemy.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:6
verses.text: Manes said: Hear, O judges, what he has said of the adversary.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:7
verses.text: He admits, then, that there are two objects.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:8
verses.text: Archelaus said: It seems to me that this man is full of madness rather than of prudence, who would stir up a controversy with me to-day because I chance to speak of the adversary.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:9
verses.text: But this objection of yours may be removed with few words, notwithstanding that you have supposed from this expression of mine that I shall allow that there are these two natures.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:10
verses.text: You have come forward with a most extravagant doctrine; for neither of the assertions made by you holds good.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:11
verses.text: For it is quite possible that one who is an adversary, not by nature, but by determination, may be made a friend, and cease to be an adversary; and thus, when the one of us has come to acquiesce with the other, we twain shall appear to be, as it were, one and the same object.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:12
verses.text: This account also indicates that rational creatures have been entrusted with free-will, in virtue of which they also admit of conversions.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:13
verses.text: And consequently there cannot be two unbegotten natures.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:14
verses.text: What do you say, then? Are these two natures inconvertible? or are they convertible? or is one of them converted? Manes, however, held back, because he did not find a suitable reply; for he was pondering the conclusion which might be drawn from either of two answers which he might make, turning the matter over thus in his thoughts: If I say that they are converted, he will meet me with that statement which is recorded in the Gospel about the trees; but if I say that they are not convertible, he will necessarily ask me to explain the condition and cause of their intermingling.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:15
verses.text: In the meantime, after a little delay, Manes replied: They are indeed both inconvertible in so far as contraries are concerned; but they are convertible as far as properties are concerned.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:16
verses.text: Archelaus then said: You seem to me to be out of your mind, and oblivious of your own propositions; yea, you do not appear even to recognise the powers or qualities of the very words which you have been learning.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:17
verses.text: For you do not understand either what conversion is, or what is meant by unbegotten, or what duality implies, or what is past, or what is present, or what is future, as I have gathered from the opinions to which you have just now given expression.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:18
verses.text: For you have affirmed, indeed, that each of these two natures is inconvertible so far as regards contraries, but convertible so far as regards properties.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 14:19
verses.text: But I maintain that one who moves in properties does not pass out of himself, but subsists in these same properties, in which he is ever inconvertible; while in the case of one who is susceptible of conversion, the effect is that he is placed outside the pale of properties, and passes within the sphere of accidents.

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 15

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 15:1
verses.text: The judges said: Convertibility translates the person whom it befalls into another; as, for example, we might say that if a Jew were to make up his mind to become a Christian, or, on the other hand, if a Christian were to decide to be a Gentile, this would be a species of convertibility, and a cause of the same.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 15:2
verses.text: But, again, if we suppose a Gentile to keep by all his own heathen properties, and to offer sacrifices to his gods, and to do service to the temples as usual, surely you would not be of opinion that he could be said to be converted, while he yet holds by his properties, and goes on in them? What, then, do you say? Do they sustain convertibility or not? And as Manes hesitated, Archelaus proceeded thus: If, indeed, he says that both natures are convertible, what is there to prevent our thinking them to be one and the same object? For if they are inconvertible, then surely in natures which are similarly inconvertible and similarly unbegotten there is no distinction, neither can the one of them be recognised as good or as evil.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 15:3
verses.text: But if they are both convertible, then, forsooth, the possible result may be both that the good is made evil, and that the evil is made good.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 15:4
verses.text: If, however, this is the possible result, why should we not speak of one only as unbegotten, which would be a conception in worthier accordance with the reckoning of truth? For we have to consider how that evil one became so at first, or against what objects he exercised his wickedness before the formation of the world.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 15:5
verses.text: When the heavens had not yet appeared, when the earth did not yet subsist, and when there was neither man nor animal, against whom did he put his wickedness in operation? whom did he oppress unjustly? whom did he rob and kill? But if you say that he first appeared in his evil nature to his own kin, then without doubt you give the proof that he comes of a good nature.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 15:6
verses.text: And if, again, all these are also evil, how can Satan then cast out Satan? But while thus reduced to a dilemma on this point, you may change your position in the discussion, and say that the good suffered violence from the evil.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 15:7
verses.text: But none the more is it without peril for you to make such a statement, to the effect of affirming the vanquishing of the light; for what is vanquished has destruction near it.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 15:8
verses.text: For what says the divine word? "Who can enter into a strong man's house, and spoil his goods, except he be stronger than he?" But if you allege that he first appeared in his evil nature to men, and only from that time showed openly the marks of his wickedness, then it follows that before this time he was good, and that he took on this quality of conversion because the creation of man was found to have emerged as the cause of his wickedness.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 15:9
verses.text: But, in fine, let him tell us what he understands by evil, lest perchance he may be defending or setting up a mere name.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 15:10
verses.text: And if it is not the name but the substance of evil that he speaks of, then let him set before us the fruits of this wickedness and iniquity, since the nature of a tree can never be known but by its fruit.

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:1
verses.text: Manes said: Let it first be allowed on your side that there is an alien root of wickedness, which God has not planted, and then I shall tell you its fruits.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:2
verses.text: Archelaus said: Truth's reckoning does not make any such requirement; and I shall not admit to you that there is a root of any such evil tree, of the fruit whereof no one has ever tasted.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:3
verses.text: But just as, when a man desires to make any purchase, he does not produce the money unless he first ascertains by tasting the object whether it is of a dry or a moist species, so I shall not admit to you that the tree is evil and utterly corrupt, unless the quality of its fruit is first exhibited; for it is written, that "the tree is known by its fruits".

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:4
verses.text: Tell us, therefore, O Manes, what fruit is yielded by that tree which is called evil, or of what nature it is, and what virtue it is, that we may also believe with you that the root of that same tree is of that character which you ascribe to it.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:5
verses.text: Manes said: The root indeed is evil, and the tree is most corrupt, but the increase is not from God.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:6
verses.text: Moreover, fornications, adulteries, murders, avarice, and all evil deeds, are the fruits of that evil root.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:7
verses.text: Archelaus said: That we may credit you when you say that these are the fruits of that evil root, give us a taste of these things; for you have pronounced the substance of this tree to be ungenerate, the fruits of which are produced after its own likeness.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:8
verses.text: Manes said: The very unrighteousness which subsists in men offers the proof itself, and in avarice too you may taste that evil root.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:9
verses.text: Archelaus said: Well, then, as you have stated the question, those iniquities which prevail among men are fruits of this tree.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:10
verses.text: Manes said: Quite so.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:11
verses.text: Archelaus proceeded: If these, then, are the fruits, that is to say, the wicked deeds of men, it will follow that the men themselves will hold the place of the root and of the tree; for you have declared that they produce fruits of this nature.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:12
verses.text: Manes said: That is my statement.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:13
verses.text: Archelaus answered: Not well say you, That is my statement: for surely that cannot be your statement; otherwise, when men cease from sinning, this tree of wickedness will appear to be unfruitful.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:14
verses.text: Manes said: What you say is an impossibility; for even though one or another, or several, were to cease sinning, there would yet be others doing evil still.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:15
verses.text: Archelaus said: If it is at all possible for one or another, or several, as you admit, not to sin, it is also possible for all to do the same; for they are all of one parent, and are all men of one lump.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:16
verses.text: And, not to follow at my ease those affirmations which you have so confusedly made through all their absurdities, I shall conclude their refutation by certain unmistakeable counter-arguments.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:17
verses.text: Do you allege that the fruits of the evil root and the evil tree are the deeds of men, that is to say, fornications, adulteries, perjuries, murders, and other similar things? Manes said: I do.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:18
verses.text: Archelaus said: Well, then, if it happened that the race of men was to die off the face of the earth, so that they should not be able to sin any more, the substance of that tree would then perish, and it would bear fruit no more.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:19
verses.text: Manes said: And when will that take place of which you speak? Archelaus said: What is in the future I know not, for I am but a man; nevertheless I shall not leave these words of yours unexamined.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:20
verses.text: What say you of the race of men? Is it unbegotten, or is it a production? Manes said: It is a production.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:21
verses.text: Archelaus said: If man is a production, who is the parent of adultery and fornication, and such other things? Whose fruit is this? Before man was made, who was there to be a fornicator, or an adulterer, or a murderer? Manes said: But if the man is fashioned of the evil nature, it is manifest that he is such a fruit, albeit he may sin, albeit he may not sin; whence also the name and race of men are once for all and absolutely of this character, whether they may do what is righteous or what is unrighteous.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:22
verses.text: Archelaus said: Well, we may also take notice of that matter.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 16:23
verses.text: If, as you aver, the wicked one himself made man, why is it that he practises his malignity on him?.

chapters.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 17

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 17:1
verses.text: The judges said: We desire to have information from you on this point, Manichaeus, to wit, to what effect you have affirmed him to be evil.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 17:2
verses.text: Do you mean that he has been so from the time when men were made, or before that period? For it is necessary that you should give some proof of his wickedness from the very time from which you declare him to have been evil.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 17:3
verses.text: Be assured that the quality of a wine cannot be ascertained unless one first tastes it; and understand that, in like manner, every tree is known by its fruit.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 17:4
verses.text: What say you, then? From what time has this personality been evil? For an explanation of this problem seems to us to be necessary.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 17:5
verses.text: Manes said: He has always been so.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 17:6
verses.text: Archelaus said: Well, then, I shall also show from this, most excellent friends, and most judicious auditors, that his statement is by no means correct.

verses.name: Archalaus and the Acts of Disputation 17:7
